raw.title: Fractals
raw.author: B. Mandelbrot
contexts: (See B. Mandelbrot's book Fractals.)
commentaries: The author references Mandelbrot's book to support the description of a boundary with fine levels of structure, analogous to a coastline.

goodreads_match.title: The Fractal Geometry of Nature
goodreads_match.description:
Clouds are not spheres, mountains are not cones, and lightning does not travel in a straight line. The complexity of nature's shapes differs in kind, not merely degree, from that of the shapes of ordinary geometry, the geometry of fractal shapes.
Now that the field has expanded greatly with many active researchers, Mandelbrot presents the definitive overview of the origins of his ideas and their new applications. The Fractal Geometry of Natureis based on his highly acclaimed earlier work, but has much broad...

The author introduces David Hilbert as a mathematician who posed a significant challenge regarding the foundations of mathematics.

commentaries: The author uses 'Principia Mathematica' as an example of a formal system in a query to illustrate how an AI system might use logical deduction and problem reduction to answer a question.

goodreads_match.title: Principia Mathematica, 3 Vols
goodreads_match.description: Principia Mathematica was first published in 1910 13; this is the ninth impression of the second edition of 1925 7. The Principia has long been recognised as one of the intellectual landmarks of the century. It was the first book to show clearly the close relationship between mathematics and formal logic. Starting from a minimal number of axioms, Whitehead and Russell display the structure of both kinds of thought. No other book has had such an influence on the subsequent history of mathematical philosophy....

raw.title: Chance and Necessity
raw.author: Jacques Monod
contexts:
Monod, Jacques.
Chance and Necessity.
New York: Random House, Vintage Books, 1971.
Paperback.
An extremel fertile mind writing in an idiosyncratic way about fascinating questions, such as how life is constructed out of non-life: how evolution, seeming_ to violate the second law of thermodynamics, is actually dependent on it.
The book excited me deeply.
commentaries: The author describes the book as written by an extremely fertile mind in an idiosyncratic way, addressing fascinating questions about life and evolution, and notes that it excited him deeply.

goodreads_match.title: Chance and Necessity
goodreads_match.description: This radical book by Nobel laureate Monod is an important intellectual event. Chance and Necessity is a philosophical statement whose intention is to sweep away as both false and dangerous the animist conception of man that has dominated virtually all Western worldviews from primitive cultures to those of dialectical materialists. He bases his argument on the evidence of modern biology, which indisputably shows, that man is the product of chance genetic mutation. With the unrelenting logic of the scientist,...

raw.author: Euclid
contexts: Aristotle codified syllogisms, and Euclid codified geometry; but thereafter, many centuries had to pass before progress in the study of axiomatic reasoning would take place again.
Euclid's Theorem about the infinitude of primes
That beautiful First Proposition by Euclid!
Readers of Euclid will grant, I suppose, that Z follows logically from A and B, so that any one who accepts A and B as true, MUST accept Z as true?
The statement-and it is called "Euclid's Theorem" (notice the capital "T")-is quite unobvious.
The operations in Euclid's brain when he invented the proof must have involved millions of neurons
He had t ambition to free Euclid of every flaw.
I would have preferred to show how to derive Euclid's Theorem (the infinitude of primes) in TNT, but it would probably have doubled the length of the book.
I am not so gullible as I was when we discussed Euclid's proof, a while back.
commentaries: The author references Euclid as the historical codifier of geometry, marking an early milestone in the formalization of mathematical reasoning.
The author cites Euclid's Theorem as another example of a proven statement in mathematics.
The Tortoise mentions Euclid's First Proposition as a subject of admiration, referring to Euclid's work, likely 'Elements'.
The author references Euclid as the source of a logical proposition, implying that readers familiar with Euclid's work would understand the logical sequence.
The author references Euclid's Theorem, a fundamental mathematical proposition, to introduce a discussion on mathematical proof and reasoning.
The author references Euclid as the historical figure who originated a mathematical proof, using his thought process to illustrate the complexity of reasoning.
The author references Euclid as the classical geometer whose work, particularly the fifth postulate, Saccheri aimed to perfect.
The author mentions Euclid's Theorem as a desirable but omitted derivation due to space constraints.
The author references a past discussion about Euclid's proof, implying Euclid as a source of mathematical or logical ideas.

goodreads_match.title_without_series: Mazes and Labyrinths: Their History and Development
goodreads_match.title: Mazes and Labyrinths: Their History and Development
goodreads_match.description:
Ever since Herodotus stood in awe before the Great Labyrinth of Egypt and its 3,000 rooms, men have been fascinated by labyrinthine puzzles, constructions, and mazes. This book explores the subject in full, with a complete illustrated account of labyrinths and mazes of all kinds, from earliest times to the present.
There are labyrinths that consist entirely of rooms and columns, like the Egyptian Labyrinth itself. There are the labyrinths of ancient history and of myth, such as the celebrated Cretan maze in...

goodreads_match.title: Magritte
goodreads_match.description: Through shock and paradox, Rene Magritte sets out to reveal the mysterious nature of thought. His paintings, with their unexpected juxtaposition of objects, are a deliberate defiance of common sense. In this classic study, Suzi Gablik explains how Magritte was never involved in the experimental techniques and stylistic innovations of the other Surrealists, and how, as a result, his work has proved to hold more options for the future. 228 illus., 19 in color.

goodreads_match.title: The Decipherment of Linear B
goodreads_match.description: The languages of the ancient world and the mysterious scripts, long undeciphered, in which they were encoded have represented one of the most intriguing problems of archaeology in modern times. This celebrated account of the decipherment of Linear B in the 1950s by Michael Ventris was written by his close collaborator in the momentuous discovery. In revealing the secrets of Linear B it offers a valuable survey of late pre-Hellenic archaeology, uncovering fascinating details of the religious and economic his...

raw.author: Paul C. Cohen
contexts:
A great contribution to modern mathematics-the demonstration that various statements are undecidable within the usual formalisms for Bibliography 746 set theory-is here explained to nonspecialists by its discoverer.
The necessary prerequisites in mathematical logic are quickly, concisely, and quite clearly presented.
commentaries: The author commends the book for clearly explaining the discoverer's own groundbreaking work on undecidability in set theory to a general audience.

contexts: This two-part Dialogue was written not by me, but by Lewis Carroll in 1895.

English French German Suite.

Lewis Carroll was fascinated by these mechanized reasoning methods, and invented many puzzles which could be solved with them.
by way of Lewis Carroll.
Just as Lewis Carroll took liberties with Zeno's Tortoise and Achilles, so have I taken liberties with Lewis Carroll's Tortoise and Achilles.
For instance, Lewis Carroll often hid words and names in the first letters (or characters) of the successive lines in poems he wrote.
This argument is very similar to the trap which the Tortoise caught Achilles in, in Lewis Carroll's Dialogue.
Once again, we are up against the issue which Lewis Carroll so sharply set forth in his Dialogue: you can't go on defending your patterns of reasoning forever.
Suite By Lewis Carroll
I believe THAT race has been written up, too, by Lewis Carroll.

raw.title: Elements
raw.author: Euclid
contexts: It all begins with Euclid, who, around 300 B.C., compiled and systematized all of what was known about plane and solid geometry in his day. The resulting work, Euclid's Elements, was so solid that it was virtually a bible of geometry for over two thousand years-one of the most enduring works of all time.
commentaries: The author introduces Euclid as the founder of rigor in mathematics and describes his work 'Elements' as a foundational and enduring text in geometry.

goodreads_match.title: Euclid's Elements
goodreads_match.description: Green Lion Press has prepared a new one-volume edition of T.L. Heath's translation of the thirteen books of Euclid's Elements. In keeping with Green Lion's design commitment, diagrams have been placed on every spread for convenient reference while working through the proofs; running heads on every page indicate both Euclid's book number and proposition numbers for that page; and adequate space for notes is allowed between propositions and around diagrams. The all-new index has built into it a glossary of Eu...

goodreads_match.title: The Pickwick Papers
goodreads_match.description: The high-spirited work of a young Dickens, THE PICKWICK PAPERS is the remarkable first novel that made its author famous and has remained one of the best-known books in the world. In it the inimitable Samuel Pickwick, his well-fed body and unsikable good spirits clad in tights and gaiters, sallies forth through the noisy streets of London and into the colorful country inns of rural England for a picaresque series of sparkling encounters with love and misadventure. From the wit of cockney bootblack Sam Welle...

raw.title: What Is Life?

goodreads_match.title_without_series: What Is Life? with Mind and Matter and Autobiographical Sketches
goodreads_match.title: What Is Life? with Mind and Matter and Autobiographical Sketches
goodreads_match.description: What Is Life? is a 1944 non-fiction science book written for the lay reader by physicist Erwin Schrodinger. The book was based on a course of public lectures delivered by Schrodinger in February 1943 at Trinity College, Dublin. Schrodinger's lecture focused on one important question: "how can the events in space and time which take place within the spatial boundary of a living organism be accounted for by physics and chemistry?" In the book, Schrodinger introduced the idea of an "aperiodic crystal" that con...

goodreads_match.title_without_series: Fads and Fallacies in the Name of Science
goodreads_match.title: Fads and Fallacies in the Name of Science
goodreads_match.description:
This witty and engaging book examines the various fads, fallacies, strange cults, and curious panaceas which at one time or another have masqueraded as science. Not just a collection of anecdotes but a fair, reasoned appraisal of eccentric theory, it is unique in recognizing the scientific, philosophic, and sociological-psychological implications of the wave of pseudoscientific theories which periodically besets the world.
To this second revised edition of a work formerly titled In the Name of Science, Mart...

raw.title: After Babel
raw.author: George Steiner
contexts: The book After Babel, by George Steiner, is a long discussion of the interaction between inner and outer messages (though he never uses that terminology).

An eloquent co-proponent of this view is the linguist and translator George Steiner, who, in his book After Babel, has written: Hypotheticals, 'imaginaries', conditionals, the syntax of counter-factuality and contingency may well be the generative centres of human speech....
George Steiner.. After Babel

George Steiner, After Babl(, pp.
215-227.

Steiner, George.
After Babel: Aspects of Language and Translation.
New York: Oxford University Press, 1975.
Paperback.
A book by a scholar in linguistics about the deep problems of translation and understanding of language by humans.
Although Al is hardly discussed, the tone is that to program a computer to understand a novel or a poem is out of the question.
A well written, thought-provoking-sometimes infuriating-book.

Steiner, who grew up trilingual, devotes several pages in After Babel to the intermingling of French, English, and German in the layers of his mind, and how his different languages afford different ports of access onto concepts.
commentaries: The author cites Steiner's book as an extended exploration of the interplay between inner and outer messages, aligning with the chapter's themes.

The author cites Steiner's book to support the view that counterfactual thinking is central to human language and cognition, quoting a passage that discusses the generative power of hypotheticals and conditionals.
The author cites George Steiner's book in the notes for a chapter on the location of meaning.
The author cites this book in a footnote, providing a page reference.

The author describes this as a well-written, thought-provoking, and sometimes infuriating book about the deep problems of translation and understanding of language, suggesting that programming a computer to understand literature is out of the question.
The author references Steiner's book 'After Babel' to discuss the intermingling of languages in a multilingual mind and how different languages provide different access points to concepts.

goodreads_match.title_without_series: After Babel: Aspects of Language and Translation
goodreads_match.title: After Babel: Aspects of Language and Translation
goodreads_match.description: When it first appeared in 1975, After Babel created a sensation, quickly establishing itself as both a controversial and seminal study of literary theory. In the original edition, Steiner provided readers with the first systematic investigation since the eighteenth century of the phenomenology and processes of translation both inside and between languages. Taking issue with the principal emphasis of modern linguistics, he finds the root of the "Babel problem" in our deep instinct for privacy and territory,....

raw.author: Gödel
contexts: Godel published his paper, which in some ways utterly demolished Hilbert's program.
via Gödel-numbering
via Gödel’s isomorphism
Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorem
The idea is to imitate Gödel’s self-referential construction, which as you know is INDIRECT, and depends on the isomorphism set up by Gödel numbering.
commentaries: The author mentions Gödel as the figure whose work undermined Hilbert's mathematical program.
The author references Gödel's method of encoding formal systems into number theory, implying reliance on Gödel's foundational work.
The author explicitly cites Gödel's isomorphism as a key concept enabling the coding of statements about formal systems into number theory.
The author references Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem as a sly remark made by the Tortoise before going home to sleep.
The author references Gödel's work on self-reference and Gödel numbering as a model for the structure of the dialogues.

raw.author: Sebastian Bach
contexts: Sebastian Bach isn't so bad, in my opinion.
the outer-space Bach record
"J. S. BACH"

Old Bach was fond of versifying, philosophizing, pipe smoking, and FIGURE 78. State of Grace, by Rene Magritte (1959). Edifying Thoughts of a Tobacco Smoker 476 music making (not necessarily in that order). He combined all four into a droll poem which he set to music. It can be found in the famous musical notebook he kept for his wife, Anna Magdalena, and it is called Edifying Thoughts of a Tobacco Smoker'
so wasn't there some way of just slightly modifying the line so that it would refer to Escher?
crab canons by Escher and Bach
the Trio Sonata, as harmonized by Bach's pupil Kirnberger
I was inspired by the one from the Musical Offering-and also by the story of the Musical Offering.
commentaries: The Tortoise mentions enjoying the music of Sebastian Bach, indicating a personal preference.
The author references Bach in the context of an imagined extraterrestrial record, using it as an example of a meaningful artifact that might be interpreted differently by other intelligences.
The author presents a visual puzzle where the letters are interpreted as spelling out the name of the composer J.S. Bach.

The author references a poem by Bach, which is contained within a musical notebook he kept for his wife, Anna Magdalena. The poem is titled 'Edifying Thoughts of a Tobacco Smoker' and is described as a combination of versifying, philosophizing, pipe smoking, and music making.
The author mentions Bach as a conceptual counterpart to Escher in the development of the dialogue, without citing a specific musical composition.
The author references the musical compositions of Bach in the context of a discussion about crab canons, indicating their relevance to the themes of symmetry and recursion.
The author references Bach's Trio Sonata as harmonized by his pupil Kirnberger, indicating a musical work by Bach that is being performed.
The author states that the final dialogue in his book is inspired by Bach's Musical Offering, specifically its form and the associated historical tale.

raw.author: Georg Cantor
contexts: A theory of different types of infinities, known as the theory of sets, was developed by Georg Cantor in the 1880's.
In our demonstration, we will use the celebrated diagonal method, discovered by Georg Cantor, the founder of set theory.

Cantor's Original Diagonal Argument Why is this called a diagonal argument? The terminology comes from Cantor's original diagonal argument, upon which many other arguments (such as ours) have subsequently been based.
commentaries: The author references Cantor as the developer of set theory, a powerful but counterintuitive mathematical framework dealing with different infinities.
The author credits Georg Cantor with the discovery of the diagonal method, which is a key technique used in the logical demonstration within the text.
The author references Cantor's original diagonal argument as the source of the terminology and foundational idea for the diagonal argument being discussed.
The author references Cantor in a list, citing him as a mathematician known for his work on set theory, but no specific book is mentioned.
